sections.title: From Property to Portfolio
sections.subtitle: Cash flow, appreciation, and leverage without the buzzwords

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: How rentals generate returns (cash flow + principal paydown + appreciation)
Why leverage magnifies both gains and losses
Key metrics: cap rate, cash‑on‑cash, and DSCR
Simple screening process for a first deal

sections.title: Three Return Engines
sections.content: Rental property returns come from (1) cash flow after expenses, (2) tenants paying down your mortgage (equity build), and (3) potential appreciation. Smart investors underwrite on conservative rents and no appreciation, so the deal works on day one.

points.title: Cap Rate
points.description: Net operating income / purchase price. Good for comparing similar properties in the same market.

points.title: Cash‑on‑Cash
points.description: Annual pre‑tax cash flow / cash invested. Reflects the return on your actual dollars in the deal.

points.title: DSCR
points.description: Debt service coverage ratio = NOI / annual debt service. Lenders prefer DSCR > 1.20 for safety.

sections.title: Leverage Cuts Both Ways
sections.content: A small rent drop can wipe out cash flow if debt is high. Keep cash reserves and stress‑test with higher vacancies and repair costs.

sections.title: Your First Deal Checklist
steps: Pick a target neighborhood and analyze 10 recent rentals for rent and expense ranges.
Build a simple underwriting sheet (rent, taxes, insurance, maintenance, vacancy, management, mortgage).
Define your walk‑away numbers (minimum cash‑on‑cash, DSCR).
Talk to one lender and one property manager to sanity‑check your assumptions.

sections.title: Buy Boring
sections.content: Predictable areas with stable tenants beat flashy zip codes with fragile math. Boring often compounds better.
